com.pump.data.branch

Interface Branch<K>

  • Type Parameters:
    K - the type of bean ids. In simple cases, this may just be a String. You can also create a more complex identifying object that represents a String ID and an object type.
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractBranch, MemoryBranch

    public interface Branch<K>
    This is a collection of bean data that keeps track of revisions.

    A branch can create a child branch which represents a snapshot of the parent branch at that instant. The child branch can merge back to the parent with a call to save(). (Otherwise: if a child branch is abandoned without saving then it should eventually be garbage collected and disappear.)

    Internally a branch considers a "bean" to basically be a map of Strings to Objects. If possible: it is preferred to use keys to refer to the keys in these maps, because that offers type safety and possible bounds checking. But that is optional, and it is up to the caller to responsibly make sure keys don't conflict with one other. (For example: if one Key object is named "roomNumber" and relates to an Integer, but another Key is also named "roomNumber" and relates to a Short: sooner or later a ClassCastException will probably result as you interact with this data, because internally both are simply keyed with the String "roomNumber".)

    It's important to note that the Revision objects this Branch interacts with are unique to this Branch. Although a Revision may contain meta information (such as timestamps, authors, comments, etc.), it is not explicitly aware of or comparable to its parent's revisions.

      • getParent

        Branch<K> getParent()
        Return the optional parent of this branch.

      • createBranch

        Branch<K> createBranch(java.lang.String name)
        Create a new child of this branch.
        Parameters:
        name - a human-readable name that may be mentioned in Exceptions or other feedback. For example, if you try to save this branch the error will be much more helpful if it can resemble: "The branch 'add new page' couldn't be added to 'root'." This is optional but recommended.
        Returns:
        a new child of this branch.

      • getName

        java.lang.String getName()
        Return the optional name of this branch.

      • addBranchListener

        void addBranchListener(BranchListener<K> branchListener)
        Add a listener that will be notified before and after a branch is saved.
        Parameters:
        branchListener - the new branch listener.

      • removeBranchListener

        void removeBranchListener(BranchListener<K> branchListener)
        Remove a BranchListener.
        Parameters:
        branchListener - the listener to remove.

      • acquireReadLock

        java.lang.Object acquireReadLock()
        Acquire a reentrant read lock. This object must be returned to releaseLock(Object).

        Implementations may choose how to reasonable manage their locks. For example, an implementation may not distinguish between a read and a write lock. Locks must be reentrant within the same thread, though.

        Returns:
        a reentrant read lock for this branch.

      • acquireWriteLock

        java.lang.Object acquireWriteLock()
        Acquire a reentrant write lock. This object must be returned to releaseLock(Object).
        Returns:
        a reentrant write lock for this branch.

      • releaseLock

        void releaseLock(java.lang.Object lock)
        Release a lock previously acquired via acquireReadLock() or acquireWriteLock().
        Parameters:
        lock - a read or write lock previously previously acquired via acquireReadLock() or acquireWriteLock().

      • getState

        BeanState getState(K beanId)
        Return the state of a bean relative to this branch.

        For example, if this branch is aware of deleting this bean, then it may return DELETED. However if this branch created this bean, deleted it, and then saved to its parent branch: the parent branch may return UNDEFINED.

        If a bean was created in a parent branch, then this may return EXISTS, but if a bean was created in this branch (and it is still exists at this point) then this should return CREATED.

        These complex scenarios are open to some interpretation by subclasses.

        Parameters:
        beanId - the id of the bean to examine.
        Returns:
        the state of this bean relative to this branch.

      • getState

        BeanState getState(K beanId,
                   Revision revision)
        Return the state of a bean relative to this branch as of a certain revision.

        For example, if this branch is aware of deleting this bean, then it may return DELETED. However if this branch created this bean, deleted it, and then saved to its parent branch: the parent branch may return UNDEFINED.

        If a bean was created in a parent branch, then this may return EXISTS, but if a bean was created in this branch (and it is still exists at this point) then this should return CREATED.

        These complex scenarios are open to some interpretation by subclasses.

        Parameters:
        beanId - the id of the bean to examine.
        revision - the latest revision to consider. If this is null you can assume you're interacting with the most recent revision.
        Returns:
        the state of this bean relative to this branch.

      • getField

        java.lang.Object getField(K beanId,
                          java.lang.String fieldName,
                          Revision revision)
                   throws MissingBeanException
        Return a field from a bean.
        Parameters:
        beanId - the bean to get the field of.
        fieldName - the name of the field to get.
        revision - the revision for which the field value should be dated. For example if a field starts out with the value of "abc" at revision #1, and then at revision #10 it becomes "xyz", then if you pass revision #5 to this method: it will return "abc".

        If this is null: the current value will be returned.

        This is used by branches to reconstruct a model of a bean based on exactly when the branch was created.

        Returns:
        the indicated field from the indicated bean as of the indicated revision, or null if that field is undefined.
        Throws:
        MissingBeanException - if the beanId provided isn't a recognized bean.

        java.lang.Object getField(K beanId,
                          java.lang.String fieldName)
                   throws MissingBeanException
        Return a field from a bean.
        Parameters:

        fieldName - the name of the field to get.
        Returns:
        the indicated field from the indicated bean, or null if that field is undefined.
        Throws:
        MissingBeanException - if the beanId provided isn't a recognized bean.

               Revision revision)

        field - the field to get.
        revision - the revision for which the field value should be dated. For example if a field starts out with the value of "abc" at revision #1, and then at revision #10 it becomes "xyz", then if you pass revision #5 to this method: it will return "abc".

        If this is null: the current value will be returned.

        This is used by branches to reconstruct a model of a bean based on exactly when the branch was created.

        Throws:

      • setField

        <V> V setField(K beanId,
               Key<V> field,
               V newValue)
        throws MissingBeanException
        Assign a field for a bean.

        This method will consult the key's bounds checkers to validate the incoming value.

        Because this performs additional validations and is parameterized, this is the prefered method to set field data if possible.

        Parameters:
        beanId - the id of the bean to modify.
        field - the field to modify.
        newValue - the new value to assign to this field (may be null).
        Returns:
        the previous value this field held, or null if it was previously undefined.
        Throws:
        MissingBeanException - if the beanId provided isn't a recognized bean.

      • setField

        fieldName - the name of the field to modify.
        newValue - the new value to assign to this field (may be null).
        Returns:
        the previous value this field held, or null if it was previously undefined.
        Throws:
        MissingBeanException - if the beanId provided isn't a recognized bean.

      • getLastRevision

        Revision getLastRevision(K beanId)
        Return the last revision in which a bean was modified, or null if this bean was never modified in this branch. Note this may be null if a bean exists but was last modified in a parent branch.
        Parameters:
        beanId - the ID of the bean to examine.
        Returns:
        the last revision in which a bean was modified. Note this may be null if a bean exists but was last modified in a parent branch.

      • getLastRevision

        Revision getLastRevision(K beanId,
                         java.lang.String fieldName)
        Return the last revision in which a particular field was modified for a given bean, or null if there is no record in this branch of any such modification.
        Parameters:
        beanId - the bean ID to examine.
        fieldName - the field to examine.
        Returns:
        the last revision in which a particular field was modified for a given bean, or null if there is no record in this branch of any such modification.

      • getLastRevision

                         Key<?> field)

        Parameters:
        beanId - the bean ID to examine.
        field - the field to examine.
        Returns:

      • getModifiedBeans

        java.util.Collection<K> getModifiedBeans()
        Return all the beans this branch modified.

        This may choose not to mention beans that were both created and destroyed in this branch.

      • setBean

        boolean setBean(K beanId,
                java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> beanData,
                boolean completeReplacement)
        Apply the key/value entries in a map to a bean in this branch.
        Parameters:
        beanId - the id of the bean to modify. If this bean does not already exist, a new bean with this ID is created.
        beanData - the data to store in this bean. This may be empty, but it may not be null.
        completeReplacement - if false then the incoming data is merged with any existing data. If true then any existing data is deleted and replaced with the previous argument.
        Returns:
        true if this created a bean, false if it modified an existing bean.

      • getBean

        java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> getBean(K beanId)
        Return all the key/value pairs for a bean.

        This consults all possible parents to create a complete representation of the bean.

        Parameters:
        beanId - the bean to fetch the key/value pairs of.
        Returns:
        a map representing all the key/value pairs in a bean, or null if the bean is undefined.

      • save

        void save()
   throws SaveException
        This saves all the changes in this branch to its parent. (This may also be considered "merge", "commit" or "push".)

        This will immediately throw a NullPointerException if there is no parent.

        This requires acquiring a read lock on this branch and a write lock on its parent.

        This method only saves changes performed since the last call to save().

        Throws:
        SaveException - if this branch contains changes that may conflict with its parent.

        This method may choose to NOT throw a SaveException if both branches modified a bean/field in the same way. For example, if both branches deleted bean X, or assigned the same value to the same field: then we don't necessarily have a collision problem.
